titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the Edwin Mims Papers

publicationstmt.publisher: Special Collections Manuscripts and Rare Books

repository.corpname: Special Collections Manuscripts and Rare Books

odd.p: Incoming correspondence of 923 letters, 16 cards, 2 telegrams. Alphabetically arranged.
Correspondence - Outgoing. Chronologically arranged. Miscellaneous letters. Letters with incomplete and illegible signatures. Outgoing correspondence (xerox copies), 1902-59 (62 letters).

did.unittitle: Autobiographical and biographical material. Class notes and lectures.
Bound volume of tributes to Edwin Mims on the occasion of his retirement. 2 scrapbooks (1894 - 1951) of, by, or of interest to Mims.
Manuscripts: Lee’s Life after the Civil War: History of Vanderbilt Adventurous America Eyes that Saw Chancellor Kirkland.
Report and discussion of faculty committee on schedules and courses of study. Book reviews. Papers of Southern Education Association and General Education Board. Micellaneous. Scrapbooks.
Microfilm of unpublished manuscript, To Seek a Newer World: The Selected Correspondence of Edwin Mims. Michael O’Brien, ed. 866 frames.
Correspondence, outgoing - letters to Clara (Puryear) Mims, arranged chronologically.

Letters to C.P.M. from others, alpha. arranged; Letters to E.M. from C.P.M., chronologically arranged; Correspondence, outgoing - general, chronologically arranged; Correspondence, incoming, alpha. arranged, A - M.
Correspondence, incoming, N - Y, plus fragments, first names only, and illegibles; Correspondence - miscellaneous (between others);
Mtl. other than correspondence is arranged alphabetically in boxes 15 - 22.

odd.p: Addresses- Mss.; Addresses, misc., untitled and extracts; The Advancing South - advertisements, etc.; Adventurous America - comments on.

Dr. Alderman - Notes on; Articles, misc. published writings about Mims, arranged chronologically; Articles, miscellaneous published writings by Mims, arranged chronologically; Autobiography - “A Forward” - “The Grand Tour”.

Autobiography - “A Bright Interval” - “Terminus? No:”; Chancellor Kirkland of Vanderbilt - advertisements, reviews; Class lectures; Clippings, misc. published material collected by Mims, arranged chronologically.
Comments by others about Mims’ lecture tours; French Diary; Lecture programs, course syllabus;
Mss. - “Anti-Lynching Movement” - “A Reconsideration of Early Southern Literature”.
Mss. - “The Romance and Realism of the West” - “The Voice of the Negro”;
Misc. lists and programs; Misc. ms. mtl., typed originals and carbons, autobiographical and ganeral;
Misc. notes, mss; Pamphlets; Passport, Photograph.
Publisher’s Mtls.; Research Notes; Scottish Diary; “The Southern Woman - Past and Present”; Travel accounts; Tributes and biographical mtl.

index.head: Index
index.p: This is a name index of the correspondents of Edwin Mims. The figure (or figures) in parentheses immediately following each name denotes the total number of letters from that person in the collection; the dates are for the time of the letters. The full name of the writer is given whenever possible; the last number given refers to the box in which the correspondence may be found.

indexentry.persname: Godding, Mrs. C. A., (co-signed by Mrs. J. G. Bowman)

(Folder is at end of outgoing correspondence in Box 3)

Articles for The Adult Student, 1920-21: “The Responsibility of Citizenship,” “The Fundamental Need,” “Myself and My Neighbor,” “The Blessedness of Work,” “Poverty and Wealth,” “The Test of the Christian Church,” “The Supreme Question for American Patriots,” “Guiding Principles for the Settlement of Social Questions.”
“The Aims of the American College,” Vanderbilt University Quarterly, XV, ii (1915). (Address, University of Virginia, February 8, 1915).

“American Ideals in American Literature,” University of North Carolina Extension Leaflets, War Information Series, No. 12, 1917.

“Chancellor James H. Kirkland and Vanderbilt University,” Southern Association Quarterly, November 1939.

“A Duty and an Opportunity,” Christian Advocate, August 20, 1903.

“Is the South Advancing or Retreating?” Southern Conference on Education.

“Leisure and Education,” Bulletin of the American Institute of Banking (address before the Pittsbrgh Convention).

scopecontent.p: This is a chronological index of Edwin Mims’ letters to Clara (Puryear) Mims. The number in parentheses following the year refers to the box in which this correspondence is to be found. The place name given in parentheses following the day and month, is the place from which the letter was sent, and includes all letters between semi-colons.

odd.p: This ia a name index of the correspondents of Edwin Mims. The number in parentheses following each name denotes the total number of letters from that person in the collection; The dates are for the time of the letters; The last number given refers to the box in which the correspondence is found.

ARTICLES, Misc. Published Writings about Mims: (arranged chronologically)
“Professor Mims at Vanderbilt,” The Charlotte Observer.
“The Richmond Conference,” The Evening Post, N.Y.
“Limericks,” Summer School Items, University of Virginia.
“Dr. Edwin Mims,” The Alumni Review, Vol. V, No. 2.
“American Literature - Triumph of National Spirit Described by Prof. Mims,” (newspaper title fragmented).
“Conflict in the South Is Outlined by Doctor Mims,” New York Commercial.
“A Southern Liberal,” The Nation, (review of The Advancing South).
“Heard and Seen “ by Fuzzy Woodruff, The Atlanta Georgian.
“The Advancing South - The Sunday Afternoon Radio Address,” The Christian Herald.
“Dr. Mims Passes By,” The Houston Gargoyle.
“By the Book,” (Review of Adventurous America), St. Louis Daily Globe-Democrat.
“Discussion of Edwin Mim’s Adventurous America,” by William S. Knickerbocker, Creative Reading - Discussions in Current Literature.
“Still Optimistic,” (Review of Adventurous America), Record, Greensboro, N.C.
“English Professor Summarizes America’s Present and Future,” by W.G. Piersel, (Review of Adventurous America), Pantagraph, Bloomington, Ill.
“Where America is Going,” (Review of Adventurous America and America Set Free by Count Hermann Keyserling), The Saturday Review.
“Myths and Realities,” by Arthur Colton (Review of Adventurous America), The Saturday Review (?).
“Book Reviews, A Contemporary Study,” (Review of Adventurous America), The West Australian, Perth, West Australia.
“A ‘Mildly Victorian’ Professor Goes Out to Meet America,” The New York Times Book Review.
“The Everlasting No - The Everlasting Yea,” Public Opinion.
“Literature of America - Visiting Professor’s First Lecture of Series,” The Citizen, St. Andrews, Scotland.
“An Interesting Visitor, Professor Mims, Tennessee, in St. Andrews,” The Citizen.
“The Southern States - Parallel with Ireland, Professor Mim’s Lecture,” The Irish Times.
“Our English Cousins’ Talents for Citizenship,” (no newspaper title).
“Dr. Edwin Mims Writes of Some Impressions Here During Summer,” Duke Alumni Register.
“Chancellor Kirkland of Vanderbilt,” The President’s Page by S.C. Garrison, The Peabody Reflector and Alumni News.
“The University’s New Venture,” Vanderbilt Alumnus, Vol. XXVI, No. 2.
“Chancellor Kirkland of Vanderbilt, A Review,” by John L. Hill, The Vanderbilt Alumnus.
“Careful Craftsmanship Mims’ Biography of Chancellor Kirkland Inaugurates Vanderbilt University Press,” by John L. Hill (Review of Chancellor Kirkland of Vanderbilt), The Nashville Banner.
“From the Shoulder,” by James G. Stahlman, The Nashville Banner,
“Chancellor Kirkland of Vanderbilt Lives in This Book,” by M.C. Huntley, (Review of Chancellor Kirkland of Vanderbilt) The Birmingham News - Age - Herald. (2 copies).
“Chancellor Kirkland of Vanderbilt; The South’s Educational Statesman,” by Jean Fligg, (Review of Chancellor Kirkland of Vanderbilt), Knoxville Journal
Letter to the Editor from Allen Tate, Vanderbilt Alumnus.
“Biography of Chancellor Kirkland Important, Interesting Picture of Education in South,” by Paul L. Palmer, (Review of Chancellor Kirkland of Vanderbilt), The Chattanooga Times.
“Story of a Great Life,” by John Erskine, (Review of Chancellor Kirkland of Vanderbilt), New York Herald Tribune, (3 copies).
“Colleagues Now Retired,” Editorial, The Vanderbilt Alumnus.
“Dr. Mims Honored at Dinner For Contribution to Education,” The Nashville Banner.
“Vanderbilt’s Growth From Small College,” by David A. Lockmiller, (A Review of History of Vanderbilt University), Chattnooga Times.
“Distinguished History of Vanderbilt,” by Robert Selph Henry, (Review of History of V.U.), The Nashville Banner.
“Vanderbilt’s History Told In Terms of Men From There,” by W.C. Teague, (Review of History of V.U.), Commercial Appeal, Memphis, Tn.
“Dr. Mims Discusses ‘Flowering’ of Culture in New England,” The Nashville Banner. (2 copies).
“Dr. Mims Cites Wholesome Provincialism in Literature,” The Nashville Banner.
“Ulysses Emeritus - He Is Still Around,” The Alumnus.
“Vandy Dynamo ‘Retirement’ Fails to Slow Edwin Mims,” The Atlanta Constitution.
“Edwin Mims: Professor-at-Large, He Has Been Classed Among the Three Greatest Teachers America Has Produced in the Twentieth Century,” The Alumnus. (2 copies, one of which is fragmented.)
“Dr. Edwin Mims, 83, Is Busier Than Ever,” by Ralph McGill, The Atlanta Constitution (This is a copy of a typed excerpt from an editorial by Ralph McGill).
“After Deciding to Teach ‘It Was Like A New Heaven And a New Earth’,” Durham Morning Herald, Durham, N.C. (On same page is an introduction of Dr. Mirna by Chancellor R.B. House of Duke Univ.).
“Address Delivered By Dr. Edwin Mims of Vanderbilt University At The Memorial Exercs Held at West Erid Methodist Church, Nashville, Feb. 11,” Peabody Alumni News.
“American Literature - Achievement of the West - Effect of Environment,” (no newspaper title).
“America’s Part ‘To a Better Internationalism’ Woodrow Wilson’s Dream,” (no newspaper title).
“Anglo-American Relations - The Importance of Literature - Some Suggested Books,” letter of J.C. Stamp to the Editor of The Times, London.
“Chancellor Kirkland of Vanderbilt,” A Review by Edgar W. Knight, The High School Journal.
“Chancellor Kirkland of Vanderbilt,” A Review by E.J.R., Christian Advocate.
“Dr. Edwin Mims Leads On Quest of High Adventures,” (no newspaper title).
“Dr. Edwin Mims Praised For His Frank Analysis Of Conditions In South,” (Review of The Advancing South), Charleston News and Courier.
“Englische Studien,” (Review of The Advancing South) by Friedrich Brie Hoops (?).
“Four Teachers, Total Age of 283, In New Posts, Come Out of Retirement and Join the New School and Teach for a Semester,” Herald Tribune, Oct. 10.
“The Frontier of The Spirit: The Firing-Line of The Soul,” The Birmingham News.
“Golden Age of Boston, St. Andrews University Lecture - Professor Edwin Mirna,” (no newspaper title).
“A Great American Hellenist: Professor Basil L. Gildersleeve,” (no newspaper title).
“A Great Educator,” (Review of Chancellor Kirkland of Vanderbilt) by Alexander Guerry (no journal title).
“A History of Vanderbilt University,” (Review of History of V.U.) by Hill Turner, Vanderbilt Alumnus Reprint.
“I Reckon So,” by T.H. Alexander, The Nashville Tennessean(?).
“Ideal And Material In South’s Life,” Nashville Banner.
“Fifty Years of Intellectual Progress,” Incidentally (column) by Nell Battle Lewis (3 copies).
“International Mind in America Stressed in Dr. Mims’ Lecture,” (no newspaper title).
“Letters and Life - In which books, plays and people are discussed,” editea by Leon Whipple (no newspaper title).
“Literature as a Nation Builder, A Review of the Mims Lecture Course,” The League Script (?).
“Mencken Boycott Urged By Dr. Mims - Vanderbilt Professor Lectures in New York on ‘Cult of Smartness,” (no newspaper title).
“On Shakespeare Jury,” picture and caption, The __?_____ Courier.
“An Optimistic Outlook,” (Review of Adventurous America), The Cornell Alumni News.
“Scotland and U.S. - Influence on American Life and Letters - St. Andrew’s Lecture,” (no newspaper title).
“Southerners Asked to End Fighting War - Dr. Edwin Mims Advocates Following Lee’s Banner to New Era - South’s Two Needs - Criticism and Larger Freedom of Thought Recommended,” (no newspaper title).
“University Day - The One Hundred and Twenty-Third Anniversary is Fittingly Observed,” The Alumni Review.
“The Youthful Mr. Mims,” The Chapel Hill Weekly.

note.p: Also included are typed excerpts from miscellaneous articles about Mims and/or his work, 1925 - 1926, (3 pages), and numerous fragments of articles which are not indexed.

did.unittitle: “Scraps and Fragments,” in The Vanderbilt Observer, Vol. XV, No.5 (E. Mims, Editor-In-Chief). May also have written the editorial. Entire issue intact.
“Shakespeare’s One Farcical Comedy,” The Chigago Record.
“Some Observations on Reading,” Charlotte Daily Observer.
“Woodrow Wilson, The Hsppy Warrior,” reprint from The Methodist Quarterly Review.
“Mark Twain’s Autobiography Season’s Most Disappointing Book,” The Tennessean.
“The Humanizing of Literature,” reprint from The English Journal, Vol. XIV, No. 6.
“The Humanities: Past and Present,” reprints from Southern Association Quarterly.
“John Maurice Webb (1847- 1916), 11 in Webb School in Celebration of Its 75th Birthday.
“Sixty Years in a Classroom,” Durham Morning Herald, Durham, N.C.
“A Southern Rebel Agctinst Romanticism,” (Review of Letters of Ellen Glasgow, edited by Blair Rouse), The Nashville Banner.
“Some By-Products of the Anti-Evolution Law,” The Nashville Tennessean.
Article about Robert E. Lee, condensed from an address given by Mims on the 80th ann;versary of Lee’s death.
Chancellor Kirkland of Vanderbilt - Advertisements, Reviews
Clippings, misc. published material collected by Mims: (arranged chronologically)

odd.p: ca. July, 1896, “Liberty, Justice, Equality,” leaflet in support of the Bentley-Southgate Ticket.
July 7, 1900, “The Ticket and Platform for the Observer’s Position,” (no newspaper title).
May 15, 1909, The Outlook, Vol. 92, No. 3. (entire issue intact).
ca. June, 1915, “Dedicated to Chancellor St. Judas and The Trustees of Kirknegiebilt University. With Apologies to Mr. G. Byron” (no source listed).

did.unittitle: “Woodrow Wilson’s Place in History,” by Jan Christian Smuts. (no journal title).
“The Impact of Science Upon Society,” by Sir Josiah Stamp, British Association for the Advancement of Society - Blackpool, 1936; The Presidential Address.
“The Moderate Nan Is At A Discount,” Public Opinion, Address by Lord Tweedsmuir, Governor-General of Canada.
“Death of Mr. Edward Garnett,” The Manchester Guardian (?).
“‘Sawney Webb’,” by William R. Webb, Jr. Reprinted from April Number of The Sewanee Review.
The Key Reporter - The Phi Beta Kappa News Magazine, Vol. XX, No. 2.
“The South and Integration:’South’s Worst Qualities Have Come Out’,” An interview with Mark Ethridge, Publisher Louisville Courier Journal, The Nashville Banner.
“The Middle of the Road - Where It Leads,” by Richard M. Weaver, Human Events.
“We Will Not Close Our Schools,” by Jonathan Daniels, North Carolina Education.
“As Calhoun Lay Dying,” by Ralph McGill.
“Do Reds Make Blues Blue?,” by Dudley Meads MacKegg.
“Lux Mundi,” Incidentally (column) by Nell Battle Lewis
“The Institute and Our Industrial Development,” by Henry M. Robinson.
“Loncoln: A Southern View,” by Archibald Rutledge, The Reviewer.
“Professor Gilbert Murray, Seventieth Birthday Honoured,” The Times, London.
“What Is ‘The Last Death’?,” by Ralph McGill.
Also 6 titled fragments, and misc. untitled fragments not indexed.
